Graphical abstract Cu@CeO2 catalytic nanomaterials have been synthesized by impregnation of ceria by copper acetate, followed by reduction and calcination under nitrogen. The components of these nanomaterials were characterized by means of XRD, XPS, N2 adsorption/desorption, TGA, SEM, and TEM microscopy techniques. The XRD spectra of ceria and Cu@CeO2_1 (3.4wt% copper loading) revealed a slight shift of the position of the planes with a small increase of the crystal lattice parameters, which can be explained by an eventual insertion of Cu0 in interstitial sites and/or a partial substitution of Ce4+ by Cu2+. Cu@CeO2 nanomaterials were found to be efficient catalysts for the N-arylation of indole with various aryl bromides to produce good yields of the desired products. The decrease in the catalytic activity of the catalyst during the reuse was probably due to oxidation of Cu0 to Cu2+ and its poisoning of KBr that was formed in situ. Keywords Nanocatalysis Ceria Cu-catalyzed N-arylation Indole 1 Introduction Catalysis is widespread in the manufacturing industry and over 60% of manufactured products have undergone at least one catalytic cycle [1]. Although homogenous and heterogenous catalysis are the two main methods of catalysis currently developed, nanocatalysis is a third option that combines the advantages of both types of previously established catalysis and is being explored by both the academic and manufacturing industries [2]. A large portion of research regarding catalysis has often focused on the metal nanoparticles supported on nanostructured materials, specifically mesoporous non-siliceous oxides [3,4]. Indeed, ceria fits into this category. It is one of the most important functional rare earth oxides [5,6], and has attracted significant interest because of its wide applications in cutting-edge technology sectors like automotive three-way catalysts, solid oxide fuel cells, UV absorption ability, gas sensors, and antioxidant therapy [7–12]. All these uses are due to certain unique properties of ceria, particularly its: inherent chemical component, high oxygen capacity, and high oxygen mobility originating from storing/releasing O2 due to the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple. However, this oxide has been widely used as a catalyst or support-catalyst of several metal nanoparticles for various chemical transformations [13–16]. Thus, Cargnello et al. demonstrated that ceria as a support has a crucial role in the catalytic activity and the interaction between the metal nanoparticles (nickel, palladium, and platinum) and this oxide (support) is decisive for the CO oxidation [17]. In another work, Li et al. conducted a comparative study on several catalysts prepared by supporting gold on different materials, namely: CeO2, TiO2, Al2O3, activated carbon, and graphene [18]. This experimental and theoretical study demonstrated that the use of ceria as support has a synergistic effect and has boosted the catalytic activity of gold. These observations led Li et al. to conclude the presence of a strong interaction and an electronic exchange between metal and ceria in comparison with the other oxides. The impregnation of ceria by copper nanoparticles or copper oxide, or vice versa (ceria-supported on copper nanoparticles), is widely studied for oxidation of CO [19,30], and organic volatile compounds [21,22], but especially for Water–Gas shift reaction [23–25]. However, it should be noted that the majority of studies revealed that there is a cooperative effect of ceria does not just have an inert support role, but also contributes to the catalytic activity of the system: metal@CeO2. Given the central importance of copper nanoparticles in boosting the catalytic activity of ceria, or reciprocally, this catalyst has been studied by using theoretical tools to elucidate and corroborate experimental data [26–28]. Alternatively, N-aryl indoles have attracted a keen interest over the last few years due to their diverse biological activities that have already been revealed and exploited [29,30]. Historically, the synthesis of these N-substituted heterocyclic compounds has been carried out via the Ullmann coupling reactions. However, these reactions generally suffered from high temperatures and the use of stoichiometric amounts of copper reagents, which make their further applications limited [31,32]. To overcome these drawbacks, another class of catalysts was developed by Buchwald and Hartwig, who separately reported that the N-arylation of nitrogen containing heterocycles with aryl halides could be achieved in the presence of appropriate copper compounds and ligands under mild conditions [33–38]. However, these homogeneous systems pose significant issues related to product purification and toxic waste produce after separation of a copper catalyst. One of the most favorable ways to overcome these problems is the realization of the N-arylation reaction via heterogeneous catalysts [39–44]. Most of these systems are copper-based catalysts in various forms, including: (i) copper nanoparticles alone or supported [45–47], (ii) copper oxides [48–53], and (iii) supported copper (Cu1+ or Cu2+) [54–59]. Relatedly, Hyeon et al. prepared CuO coated copper nanoparticles by thermal decomposition, using copper acetylacetonate. They then reported the use of this nanostructured material to catalyze the Ullmann amination coupling reaction of various aryl chlorides [60]. In another example, Choudary et al. designed a catalyst for N-arylation of imidazoles via the cation exchange of fluorapatite and tert-butoxyapatite with copper [61]. In light of these facts, Choudary et al. discovered this reaction by using arylboronic acids and obviously a copper-exchanged fluorapatite-like catalyst [62]. Another kind of material to catalyze the N-arylation reaction has been developed recently; it comes from a nanostructured mixed oxide, based on iron and copper [63]. Zhang et al. synthesized and then tested a series of magnetic mixed oxides (CuFe2O4, MgFe2O4, NiFe2O4, MnFe2O4, CoFe2O4). These authors revealed that CuFe2O4 was the best of all the prepared oxides, with an excellent yield obtained [64]. It is in light of these studies that this work is situated. The objective of this study is the synthesis and characterization of ceria doped with copper nanoparticles, and then its use as a catalyst in the reaction of N-arylation of indole with bromo-aryl derivatives (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and apparatus All commercial reagents were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Company and were used without further purification. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted under air or nitrogen in a TA Instrument Q500 apparatus, with a 10°C/min ramp between 25 and 1000°C. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of samples in KBr pellets was measured on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrometer. X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained at room temperature on a Bruker AXS D-8 diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation in Bragg–Brentano geometry (θ–2θ). TEM micrographs were obtained on a Tecnai G2 microscope at 120kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy analysis was carried out on a Jeol 2100F microscope, equipped with a high-resolution pole piece, field emission gun and operating at 200kV. The gas adsorption data was collected using a Micromeritics 3Flex Surface characterization analyzer, using N2. Prior to N2 sorption, all samples were degassed at 150°C overnight. The specific surface areas were determined from the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (at −196°C), using the BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) method. Pore size distributions were calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms with the “classic theory model” of Barret, Joyney and Halenda (BJH) [65]. XPS studies were carried out in a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al-Kα X-ray source (hν =1486.6eV) operating at 150W, a multi-channel plate and delay line detector under 1.0×10−9 Torr vacuum. The survey and high-resolution spectra were collected at fixed analyzer pass energies of 160 and 20eV, respectively. The instrument work function was calibrated to give an Au 4f7/2 metallic gold binding energy of 83.95eV. The spectrometer dispersion was adjusted to give a binding energy of 932.63eV for metallic Cu 2p3/2. Samples were mounted in floating mode in order to avoid differential charging; charge neutralization was required for all samples. The electronic binding energy of C 1s (284.80eV) was used as the internal standard. The data was analyzed with commercially available software, CasaXPS. The individual peaks were fitted by a Gaussian (70%)–Lorentzian (30%) (GL30) function after Shirley type background subtraction. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst 2.2.1 Preparation of ceria For preparation of ceria powder by the co-precipitation method, high purity (99.5%) ammonium cerium (IV) nitrate (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 and ammonia (NH4OH) were used. In a typical procedure, ammonia (25%) was added by the drop to an aqueous solution of ammonium cerium (IV) nitrate, which was prepared by solubilizing 1g of cerium precursor in 100mL of water. The ammonia was added until a basic pH (∼12) was reached. Thus, the reaction took place under vigorous stirring during 4h, at 70°C. The obtained light yellow precipitate was separated by centrifugation and washed with water several times. The obtained solid was dried overnight at 80°C under vacuum and calcined for 3h at 550°C to lead to cerium oxide. 2.2.2 Preparation of Cu@CeO2 The preparation of Cu@CeO2 was performed by impregnating the ceria with copper acetate with a loading of 3.4 and 7wt%, followed by the reduction of the Cu2+ to copper nanoparticles. The first step was to dissolve copper acetate (∼0.54mmol) in 10mL of diethylene glycol, where another aqueous solution of sodium dodecyl sulfate (0.1M), was subsequently added. In the second step, 1g of previously prepared ceria was added to the first mixture and stirred at 70°C for 24h. The pH of this mixture was adjusted to pH>10 by adding NH4OH. Then, hydrazine hydrate (80%, 1mL) was added to reduce Cu2+ to copper nanoparticles. In the final step, the resulting powder was filtered and sequentially washed with ethanol and acetone, dried at 80°C under vacuum, and finally calcined at 550°C under nitrogen for 3h. According to the measurement of copper content, the aforementioned procedure led to two catalysts: Cu@CeO2_1 (3.4wt%) and Cu@CeO2_2 (7wt%). 2.2.3 General procedure for the N-arylation of NH heterocycles with aryl bromides 5mol% of catalyst was added to a stirred mixture of indole (0.5mmol), 4-bromotoluene (1mmol), KOH (1mmol), and 1,10-phenanthroline (0.256mmol). The reaction mixture was refluxed in 2mL of dimethylsulfoxyde for 24h. The reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was removed by filtration, and the mixture was diluted with water and extracted with dichloromethane (3× 10mL). The organic phase was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, concentrated and then subjected to flash column chromatography on silica gel, which led to the isolation of the desired product. The structures of the prepared products were confirmed by 1H NMR and were assigned on the basis of their spectral data in comparison to those reported in other literature. The recovered catalyst was washed twice with dichloromethane and water, and dried at 100°C before being reused in subsequent reactions to demonstrate its prolonged activity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Once the materials were prepared, a systematic analysis was needed in order to correlate their structural, textural and morphological properties to their catalytic activity. Therefore, TGA was used to determine the calcination temperature and the thermal stability of the products. It should be noted that all samples that were prepared as part of this study have been previously analyzed by this technique (see Supporting Information). Thus, the thermal stability of dried Cu@CeO2_1 was examined by TGA analysis under nitrogen (Fig. 1 ), and under air (Fig. S3). It is evident that the analysis under nitrogen clearly exhibited three steps of weight loss, and while under air it decomposed in two major steps. In the nitrogen analysis, the first weight loss of 70–110°C relates to the loss of water molecules. The second weight loss was 150–280°C, which was due to the degradation of organic molecules. The third loss above 500°C relates to maturation and crystallization of copper nanoparticles. TGA under air shows similar characteristics, but weight loss occurred toward higher temperatures (700–860°C). This observation corresponds to the formation of CuO@CeO2_1, which was subsequently confirmed by XRD (Fig. S4). Fig. 2 represents the powder X-ray diffraction spectra of the ceria obtained by co-precipitation, and ceria-supported copper at two different copper loadings (Cu@CeO2_1, Cu@CeO2_2). Firstly, the XRD pattern (Fig. 1a) confirmed that the as-synthesized ceria exhibits a face-centered cubic fluorite structure (Fm3m; JCPDS card no. 34-0394). In the Cu@CeO2_1 sample, all the peaks are attributable to the ceria. By cons, the diffractogram of the Cu@CeO2_2 sample showed the presence of a secondary phase in which the diffraction peaks correspond to metallic copper. However, the Rietveld refinement allowed the estimation of the lattice parameters of the three samples: ceria, Cu@CeO2_1 and Cu@CeO2_2 (Table 1 , Fig. S6). The criteria (Rp, Rwp and χ 2) indicate the quality of this refinement. The value obtained for the undoped sample (ceria) is 0.54112nm, which is close to the standard value previously reported (a =0.541134nm, JCPDS 34-0394). An increase in the lattice parameter is observed in the doped samples (Table 1), which is consistent with the shift of the diffraction peaks (Fig. S5). The increase in the lattice parameter is linear up to a doping level of 7%, loading corresponding to the appearance of the secondary phase (Cu0 NPs). The conservation of the crystallographic structure of the ceria and the increase of the lattice parameter suggest that the samples are solid solutions of substitution in which the cerium is replaced by copper. The solubility limit of copper in the ceria lattice seems to be between 3.4% and 7% loading into copper or doping percentage. The evolution of the lattice parameter of ceria dependent upon the loading of copper is shown in Fig. 3 . The lattice parameter of ceria increases with the increase of the percentage of doping of copper. This is in accordance with the observed shift of the diffraction peaks. It should be noted that the ionic radius of the cupric ions (rCu2+ =0.081nm) is lower than that of Ce4+ ions (rCe4+ =0.097nm). Both scenarios may be presented in the case of the insertion of a small doping element within the unit cell of ceria. In the first scenario, the doping element can occupy the atomic positions of Ce4+ ions. In this case, the lattice parameter varies with the size of the doping element. With copper, the positive charge deficiency leads to the creation of oxygen vacancies. The formula for the substituting solid solution is then Ce1−x Cu x O2−x , where x is the doping percentage into copper. In the second scenario, the doping element is able to occupy interstitial sites, apart from the atomic positions of Ce4+ ions. In this situation, the lattice parameter may increase even if the dopant is smaller than Ce4+cation. The formula of the interstitial solid solution is Ce1−(1/2)x Cu x O2 in the case of Cu2+. This insertion mechanism does not cause deficiency in positive charges, and thus does not lead to the formation of oxygen vacancies. In our case, the increase of the lattice parameter suggests that copper ions are not substituted by cerium ions but occupy interstitial sites in the structure of ceria, which causes an expansion of the lattice and an increase in its volume. The increase of the lattice parameter seems to reach a threshold with the appearance of the secondary phase when the ceria is doped by 7% of copper. The metallic copper appearance of the secondary phase (Cu0 of cubic structure, JCPDS no. 85-1326) indeed indicates that copper saturates the unit cell. The cupric ions can no longer get into the unit cell and no longer affect its volume. The projection of crystal unit cell of ceria and Cu@CeO2 (3.4wt%) is shown in Fig. 4 . This projection viewed along the b-axis shows the spatial distribution of ceria and the unit cell of Cu@CeO2 (3.4wt%), illustrating the sequence of units and the location of copper ions within the crystal lattice. The FTIR spectra of CeO2, Cu@CeO2_1 and Cu@CeO2_2 are presented in Fig. 5 . The three spectra show the bands at 3300 and 1640cm−1corresponding to the −OH stretching vibration and to the H2O bending vibration, respectively [66]. The fingerprint of ceria is assigned in FTIR spectroscopy to the CeOCe stretching vibration, which is detected toward 400cm−1 [67]. It is noteworthy that the three spectra are similar in the existence of the characteristic band of ceria in the three cases, which proves that the base framework of the structure does not change when ceria is loaded with copper. The surface compositions and chemical states of Cu@CeO2_1 were studied by using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Fig. 6 , spectra (a), shows the Ce 3d core-level spectra of the Cu@CeO2_1. Indeed, we detected the existence of two oxidation states of cerium (Ce4+ and Ce3+), which can be explained by the complex structure of the core-level Ce 3d spectra [68]. The highest binding energy peaks located at approximately 916.9 and 898.3eV, respectively, are the result of a Ce 3d94f0 O 2p6. These satellite peaks are characteristic of the presence of Ce4+ ions. However, the other peaks are characteristic of Ce3+. In addition, the O 1s core-level peak from the lattice oxygen in Cu@CeO2 was detected at about 529.44 and 531.48eV, respectively (spectra (c)). The presence of these two peaks is due to the presence of CeOCu bonds and Ce3+ states [20]. The Cu 2p3/2 peak at 932.68eV was assigned to Cu0 (spectra (b)). The Cu 2p3/2 peak at 934.28eV suggested the presence of a Cu2+ states. This can be alternatively interpreted with a possible electronic exchange between copper and ceria, which has been partially reduced to CeO x . The XRD corroborate these observations, showing only the characteristic peaks of CeO2 that are incorporated into its structure of copper. The UV–vis spectroscopy analysis of all prepared materials also confirms the XPS observations. Thus, the UV–vis spectra of CeO2, Cu@CeO2_1 and Cu@CeO2_2, show three characteristic peaks at 222, 307 and 370nm, respectively (Fig. 7 ). These peaks are assigned to f–d transitions of Ce3+ species, low coordination Ce4+ O charge transfer and inter-band transitions in CeO2, respectively. The shoulder at 400–560nm can be attributed to d–d transition of Cu in Cu@CeO2 [69] or absorption from the conduction band of metallic copper [70]. The UV–visible spectra analysis of the Cu@CeO2 samples is more complex due to overlapping of the above mentioned bands, related to the presence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ cations and bands assigned to the various forms of copper: Cu0 and Cu2+. SEM was used to study the morphology of the surface of ceria and Cu@CeO2_1 (Fig. 8 ). These micrographs show that both materials had a heterogeneous microstructure that consisted of crystallites of various sizes and forms, with an irregular surface roughness. It should be noted that the morphology of ceria does not undergo a major change after loading with 3.4% of copper. TEM analysis of ceria and ceria-supported copper revealed that both samples are well nanostructured with a quasi-spherical morphology and a particle size range from 9 to 15nm (Table 2 ). It should be noted that the TEM images of the Cu@CeO2_2, presented in the Supporting Information (Fig. S7), are typical of a nanostructured material with an average size of 10nm. In addition, the estimated crystallite size by Scherrer's equation was also summarized in Table 2. Since the nanoparticles are agglomerated, we note that the dispersion of both samples is relatively heterogeneous, especially after the doping of ceria by copper. This observation can be explained by the Ostwald ripening phenomena. The HR-TEM technique was also used in order to analyze mostly the inter-planar distances of the local structure of the catalyst. The images (c)–(e) in Fig. 8 show the representative HR-TEM images of Cu@CeO2_1. These images show the arrangement of nanoparticles in this structure, which is characterized by its special egg or ellipsoid shape (e). The measured inter-planard spacing on the image (d) is near 3.14Å, which corresponds to the atomic plane (111) of the fluorite structure of ceria. This slight increase in the distance confirms the swelling of the crystal lattice of the cerium oxide after its doping by copper. This observation is in perfect harmonization with the results of XRD. Furthermore, we note that these observations are corroborated by the SEAD (Fig. 9f). The calculated texture parameters of ceria, Cu@CeO2_1 and Cu@CeO2_2 are summarized in Table 2. It can be seen that the BET surface area of ceria is 31m2/g and its pore volume is 0.0521cm3/g, while the surface area of the Cu@CeO2_1 is 45m2/g and its pore volume 0.1655cm3/g. The increase of the copper content has a significant effect on the surface area and pore volume. Thus, for the sample prepared with 7wt% copper, the surface area is 12m2/g and the pore volume is 0.0566cm3/g. The nitrogen sorption isotherm of Cu@CeO2_1 is of type IV, displaying hysteresis loops in the relative pressure range of 0.6–0.9 and plateaus in the adsorption branches, indicating its mesoporous nature (Fig. 10a). The corresponding pore size distribution curve (Fig. 10b) indicates that Cu@CeO2_1 has a centralized pore size distribution within two areas toward 4 and 17nm, corresponding to mesoporous materials. The shape of the isotherm of ceria (Fig. S8) is not exactly identical to that of Cu@CeO2_1. It was initially characterized as either type IV or V, since the hysteresis loop manifests the existence of open mesopores, which are characteristic of type IV or V isotherms. The hysteresis loop is of type H3 according to the IUPAC description system. As shown in Fig. S9, the nitrogen sorption isotherms of the ceria and Cu@CeO2_2 exhibits a hysteresis loop in the relative pressure range above 0.90, and a plateau does not appear in the adsorption branch. These observations indicate the existence of open mesopores. 3.2 N-arylation of indoles over nanostructured catalysts In an effort to find the best catalytic system, various catalysts such as ceria, Cu@CeO2_1, Cu@CeO2_2, CuO@CeO2, Cu nanoparticles, and Cu(OAc)2were screened for the N-arylation of indole with 4-bromotoluene (Scheme 2 ). The results are summarized in Table 3 . First, it should be noted that a reaction without a catalyst did not occur (Table 3, entry 1), and the ceria alone as a catalyst was also inactive in this reaction (Table 3, entry 2). However, the doping of ceria by copper had a significant effect on catalytic activity (Table 3, entries 3 and 4). The yields were, respectively, 86 and 80% for Cu@CeO2_1 and Cu@CeO2_2. We note that Cu@CeO2_1 gave a yield slightly higher than Cu@CeO2_2. This slight difference may be explained by the difference in crystallographic and electronic structures between the two samples. Thus, the existence of two couples Ce4+/Ce3+ and Cu2+/Cu0, which were revealed by XPS, with the high concentration of O2− in the support (ceria), makes the Cu@CeO2_1 catalytic system more effective, since it is highly probable that there is an electronic exchange between these couples red/ox existing in the same crystal lattice. This increases in the concentration of copper metal is a key element in this chemical process because the limiting step requires Cu0. To argue this interpretation, we conducted this reaction in the absence of any ligand and the yield obtained was 51% (Table 3, entry 5). This demonstrated the existence of some percentage of Cu0, which is perfectly correlated with the XPS data. The use of mixed oxide CuO@CeO2 prepared by co-precipitation with a loading of 3.4% copper gave a very low yield (Table 3, entry 6), corroborating with the above interpretation, and revealing that the electronic structure of the copper is crucial to catalyze this reaction. By cons, catalysis by copper nanoparticles (Cu0) formed in situ, translated to a yield of 79%, which is somewhat similar to the yield obtained by Cu@CeO2_1 (Table 3, entry 7). The last test was performed using homogeneous Cu(OAc)2 as the catalyst and led to very low yield. These results clearly show the importance of our catalytic system developed in this work in comparison with the homogeneous catalysis. The effect of other parameters, namely: type of solvent, nature of the base, reaction temperature, and catalyst loading was also investigated. The results obtained are summarized in Table 4 . We initially noted that the DMSO and DMF, which have the highest dipole moments and boiling temperatures, gave the best yields (Table 4, entries 4 and 8). Acetonitrile and dioxane are both highly polar solvents in the same range as DMSO and DMF and have boiling temperatures less than the other two solvents (DMSO and DMF). We obtained yields unless in both other cases (Table 4, entries 5 and 7). With the use of toluene (Table 4, entry 6), we obtained 66% yield, which justified the influence of solvent polarity. Interestingly, when DMF was used as the solvent, we observed that this reaction was sensitive to temperature (Table 4, entries 1–4). According to these studies (nature of solvents and reaction temperature), we can conclude that temperature is a key parameter in this type of reaction. The study of the influence of the nature of the base shows that the best yields were obtained by using strong bases such as: NaOH and KOH (Table 4, entries 8 and 9). By cons, when we used K2CO3 (pKa=10.2) and pyridine (pKa=5.229), the obtained yields were 60 and 57%, respectively. The use of cerium oxide, which inherently has a basic character [71], only gave 25% in yield. However, the absence of the base completely inhibits the N-arylation of indole (Table 4, entry 13) (knowingly, the base has a key role in the catalytic cycle by snatching the acid proton of the indole). The comparison between 2,2′-bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline shows that these ligands give quantitative yields (Table 4, entries 8, 14), but with a higher performance like 1,10-phenanthroline. This dissimilarity can be explained by the variation in the spatial distribution of each ligand. Thus, 1,10-phenanthroline, which has a rigid and stable structure can stabilize more Cu0. By cons, the electron cloud is so delocalized and the rotation of the CC bond is so strong in 2,2′-bipyridine that the stabilization of Cu0 is a bit difficult. On the other hand, the decrease of the catalyst loading by half gave a yield of 72% (Table 4, entry 14), which demonstrated the influence of the mass of catalyst in this type of reaction. Once the optimal conditions for this reaction model were established, we looked at examining the utility of this methodology. In order to generalize the reaction of N-arylation, we used Cu@CeO2_1 as the catalyst, KOH as the base, 1,10-phenanthroline as the ligand and DMSO as the solvent under refluxing condition. Thus, the scope of the N-arylation of indole was tested with respect to other aryl bromides; the results of the test are shown in Table 5 . Initially, the substitution effects of aryl bromides were investigated. Thus, the substituted aryl bromides gave quantitative yields independent of the kind of substitutions used (electron withdrawing, electron donating) (Table 5, entries 1–4) and their positions (Table 5, entries 1 and 3). Under the above optimal conditions, 1-bromonaphthalene underwent the CN coupling reaction with excellent yield, in spite of the effect of steric hindrance (Table 5, entry 5). Thereafter, 2-bromopyridine was effectively coupled with an indole to afford the desired coupling product in a good yield, under the same experimental conditions (Table 5, entry 6). Besides activity and selectivity, one expected advantage of supported catalytic systems lies in the easy separation of catalytic materials and possible recycling of the system (depending on its robustness). After a catalytic test, the Cu@CeO2_1 powder was filtered, rinsed with a small portion of dichloromethane, and dried under vacuum for 4h. A second catalytic cycle was successfully achieved for the N-arylation of indole with 4-bromotoluene under the same conditions. The catalyst was recyclable for up to three cycles, although a progressive decrease in activity was observed (Table 6 ). In order to clarify the behavior of Cu@CeO2_1 during recycling experiments, post-catalysis characterizations were conducted. The oxidation state of the catalyst after one catalytic cycle was examined by XPS. The obtained results revealed that the degree of oxidation state of cerium and copper were not changed (Fig. 11 ) except that their concentrations were reduced in comparison with XPS of fresh catalyst. By cons, we note the presence of the K+ with values compatibles to K+ of the KBr in the recovered catalyst, which may explain the linear decrease of yield after each reuse (as has already been reported) [72]. To investigate the heterogeneity of the catalyst, the solid catalyst was suspended in DMSO for 24h under reflux. After that, the catalyst was filtered and the reaction mixture of indole, 4-bromotoluene, base and 1,10-phenanthroline were added to the filtrate. After 24h, there was not any product was detected. These results suggest that the solid catalyst caused the N-arylation reaction. Also noteworthy is the reuse of Cu@CeO2_2 that gave 74% yield in comparison with the fresh catalyst. The XRD analysis revealed more significant and informative differences. In the recovered catalyst, we observed the appearance of a third crystal phase that corresponded to copper oxide. It is clear that copper nanoparticles in the used catalyst (Cu@CeO2_2) are oxidized to copper (II) (Fig. S10). 4 Conclusions In summary, the work undertaken was aimed at exploring new ways to synthesize nanostructured catalysts based on ceria-supported copper. The impregnation of the ceria by copper acetate followed by reduction and calcination under nitrogen, leads to the formation of two nanostructured catalysts. Physicochemical properties of these materials were evaluated by FT-IR, XRD, SEM, TEM, TGA, BET, XPS as well as UV. A Rietveld refinement was performed to provide a clear idea about the structure of the Cu@CeO2, especially on the site where copper exists in the crystal lattice of ceria. First, a study of the evaluation and screening of catalysts was achieved to find the best catalyst for N-arylation reaction of indole with 4-bromotoluene. This study revealed that the Cu@CeO2_1 gave the best yield compared to the other catalytic systems tested. This can be explained by an eventual interaction of copper with the support, which stabilized the metallic states of copper. Thereafter, we studied the effect of several parameters to optimize the catalytic process. The said optimum conditions were adopted to generalize this process to different aryl bromides. The yields obtained were generally quantitative. The possibility to reuse the catalyst was also realized with the use of XPS, which is an important analytical tool for this type of study. From characterization of the Cu@CeO2_1, we showed that Cu was present in the Cu0 and Cu2+ states before and after reaction. This was assigned to a reversible exchange of electrons during the reaction between the support (ceria) and the couple Cu2+/Cu0. The decrease in the catalytic activity of Cu@CeO2_1 can be explained by a catalyst poisoning of K and Br ions, which are formed in situ during the reaction and get stuck on the catalyst surface even after washing. By cons, the study of the reuse of Cu@CeO2_2 (7wt%) shows that the yield of the model reaction was decreased, and the analysis of the recovered catalyst by XRD revealed the existence of a third phase of crystallographic that corresponded to the copper oxide (CuO). This indicated that the isolated copper nanoparticles were oxidized. The characterization and the application of this material in the catalyzation of the N-arylation reaction of indole were major assets, illustrating the originality of this research work. The transfer of this kind of catalysts in other catalytic processes is presently being examined in our laboratory, and further research will focus on the development of new nanostructured catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Cu@CeO2 catalytic nanomaterials have been synthesized by impregnation of ceria by copper acetate, followed by reduction and calcination under nitrogen. The components of these nanomaterials were characterized by means of XRD, XPS, N2 adsorption/desorption, TGA, SEM, and TEM microscopy techniques. The XRD spectra of ceria and Cu@CeO2_1 (3.4wt% copper loading) revealed a slight shift of the position of the planes with a small increase of the crystal lattice parameters, which can be explained by an eventual insertion of Cu0 in interstitial sites and/or a partial substitution of Ce4+ by Cu2+. Cu@CeO2 nanomaterials were found to be efficient catalysts for the N-arylation of indole with various aryl bromides to produce good yields of the desired products. The decrease in the catalytic activity of the catalyst during the reuse was probably due to oxidation of Cu0 to Cu2+ and its poisoning of KBr that was formed in situ.
coredata.dc:title: Ceria-supported copper nanoparticles: A highly efficient and recyclable catalyst for N-arylation of indole
